elements.content: We have obtained a suite of two-dimensional layered isostructural coordination polymers [M­(pypa)2­(H2O)2] n (M = Mn (1), Co (2), Ni (3), Cu (4), respectively), Hpypa = 1H-[3-(4-pyridy)­pyrazole]­propionic acid), and used them in catalyzing the homocoupling of aromatic halides. 3 and 4 exhibit preeminent catalytic performance on the homocoupling of aryl bromide or aryl iodide without byproducts, while 2 only promoted the homocoupling of aryl iodide. But 1 showed no catalytic activities for all tested aromatic halides. Subsequently, density functional theory was performed for the balanced geometry frameworks, net charges of atoms, and energy of frontier molecule orbits. By using this method we determined that the catalytic performance was influenced by central metal ions. For further improving the catalytic performance, polyvinylpyrrolidone or polyethylene glycol 20000 (PEG 20000) was used as surfactants to synthesize the microscales of 3’s (3a and 3b). 3a and 3b showed more preeminent catalytic activity than 3.

elements.content: A series of two-dimensional layered isostructural coordination polymers have been successfully isolated under solvothermal conditions by the reaction of a pyridine carboxylic ligand together with M2+ (M = Mn, Co, Ni, Cu) salts. The difference of central metals leads to isostructural M frameworks showing different catalytic activity for the synthesis of biaryl derivatives. Density functional theory was performed for the balanced geometry structures, net charges of atoms, and energy of frontier molecule orbits. By this method we explain the influence of central metal ions on the catalytic performance.

elements.content: The biaryl motif is found widely in natural products, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and materials. Hence scientists devote their energies to the development of effective synthetic approaches for biaryl formation. Homo- and cross-coupling reactions (named as Ullmann reactions) are continually adopted building C–C bonds, especially for building biaryl structures and heteroaromatic analogues. Historically, the Ullmann reaction of aromatic halides was the first successful method to prepare symmetric biaryls by copper metal as catalysts. As the Ullmann reactions demand the expenditure of equimolar mixtures of copper and a severe reaction temperature of over 200 °C, multifarious catalysts, such as nickel, palladium, MnCl2, FeCl3, CoBr2, CuCl2, etc., were introduced into the reaction subsequently with milder reaction conditions. In the homocoupling reaction catalyzed by palladium or nickel, a reducing agent, such as carbonic monoxide gas, hydroquinone (HQ), or hydrogen gas, is necessary. However, the above reactions involve Grignard reagents, causing the reactions to be moisture-sensitive and difficult to control. The traditional catalysts are usually homogeneous catalysts, which makes their cyclic utilization almost impossible. These kinds of metal catalysts and the reducing agents are expensive or toxic. Thus, new efficient and environment-friendly heterogeneous catalysts are still needed.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The biaryl motif is found widely in natural products, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and materials. Hence scientists devote their energies to the development of effective synthetic approaches for biaryl formation. Homo- and cross-coupling reactions (named as Ullmann reactions) are continually adopted building C-C bonds, especially for building biaryl structures and heteroaromatic analogues. Historically, the Ullmann reaction of aromatic halides was the first successful method to prepare symmetric biaryls by copper metal as catalysts. As the Ullmann reactions demand the expenditure of equimolar mixtures of copper and a severe reaction temperature of over 200 °C, multifarious catalysts, such as nickel, palladium, MnCl2, FeCl3, CoBr2, CuCl2, etc., were introduced into the reaction subsequently with milder reaction conditions. In the homocoupling reaction catalyzed by palladium or nickel, a reducing agent, such as carbonic monoxide gas, hydroquinone (HQ), or hydrogen gas, is necessary. However, the above reactions involve Grignard reagents, causing the reactions to be moisture-sensitive and difficult to control. The traditional catalysts are usually homogeneous catalysts, which makes their cyclic utilization almost impossible. These kinds of metal catalysts and the reducing agents are expensive or toxic. Thus, new efficient and environment-friendly heterogeneous catalysts are still needed.

elements.content: Fortunately, coordination polymers (CPs), a new kind of porous material, provide a new tunable platform to fabricate well-defined molecular single-site catalysts. Compared with homogeneous catalysts, CPs-based heterogeneous catalysts possess a high level of porosity, activities catalytic centers, and precise structures and functionality. CPs-type heterogeneous catalysts are easy to construct via self-assembly or postsynthetic approaches. From the reported references, the study is concentrated on the relation between the structures of heterogeneous catalysts and the size of reaction substrates. The influence of central metals to catalytic behaviors has not been researched and discussed. It has been observed that the catalytic performance of CPs-based heterogeneous catalysts is strongly dependent on the metal entities. To systematically gain a deep understanding of the relationships between the identity of central metals and the catalytic behaviors, synthesis and research of isostructural coordination polymers based on the same ligand and different metal ions would find the relation between the central metals and the catalytic behavior without the influence of ligands and geometries.

CPs-type heterogeneous catalysts are easy to construct via self-assembly or postsynthetic approaches. The influence of central metals to catalytic behaviors has not been researched and discussed. It has been observed that the catalytic performance of CPs-based heterogeneous catalysts is strongly dependent on the metal entities. To systematically gain a deep understanding of the relationships between the identity of central metals and the catalytic behaviors, synthesis and research of isostructural coordination polymers based on the same ligand and different metal ions would find the relation between the central metals and the catalytic behavior without the influence of ligands and geometries.

elements.content: For specific investigating of the relation, we selected 1H-[3-(4-pyridy)­pyrazole]­propionic acid (Hpypa) as the ligand, because Hpypa possesses N- and O-potential electron-donating centers, which are beneficial to prepare the coordination polymers with different metals. More important is that Hpypa exhibits relatively limited coordination modes. It is good for preparing isostructural coordination polymers with different metal ions. As we expect, four isostructural coordination polymers have been synthesized successfully, namely, [M­(pypa)2(H2O)2] n (M = Mn (1), Co (2), Ni (3), Cu (4), respectively). 3 and 4 exhibited more prominent catalytic activities on the homocoupling of aromatic halides than 2. 1 showed no catalytic activities for aromatic halides. Subsequently, 3’s microscale 3a and 3b were achieved with the increase of different surfactants as templates and showed more prominent catalytic activity. Moreover, density functional theory (DFT) was performed for the balanced geometry frameworks, net charges of atoms, and energy of frontier molecule orbit, and it was determined that the factors of central metals influence the catalytic performances.

elements.content: All the reagents and solvents used were commercially sourced and utilized without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were tested on a FLASH EA 1112 elemental analyzer. The data of thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were collected using a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer in air (heat rate of 10 °C min–1). 1H and 13C NMR spectra were carried out on Avance-400 spectrometers. Mass spectra (MS) were produced on an Agilent Technologies 6420 Triple Quad LC/MS without the LC part. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a PANalytical X’Pert PRO diffractometer by Cu Kα1 radiation. A Bruker-ALPHA spectrophotometer, which employs KBr pellets, was adopted to record the Fourier transform infrared spectra of complexes within the 400–4000 cm–1 scale.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All the reagents and solvents used were commercially sourced and utilized without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were tested on a FLASH EA 1112 elemental analyzer. The data of thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were collected using a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer in air (heat rate of 10 °C min-1). 1H and 13C NMR spectra were carried out on Avance-400 spectrometers. Mass spectra (MS) were produced on an Agilent Technologies 6420 Triple Quad LC/MS without the LC part. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a PANalytical X'Pert PRO diffractometer by Cu Kα1 radiation. A Bruker-ALPHA spectrophotometer, which employs KBr pellets, was adopted to record the Fourier transform infrared spectra of complexes within the 400-4000 cm-1 scale.

elements.content: A solution of Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O (17.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) or polyethylene glycol (PEG) 20000 (50 mg) and H2O (4 mL) was mixed and sonicated for 30 min until the whole PVP or PEG 20000 dissolved. DMF (4 mL) and Hpypa (10.8 mg, 0.05 mmol) was added into the PVP (or PEG 20000)/H2O mixture and it was sonicated for the other 30 min. Therewith, the mixture solution was put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave under 100 °C for 3 days. After being cooled, microcrystals were obtained via centrifugation at 10 000 rpm in 10 10 min. Then, the supernatant was removed, and the microcrystals were produced by redispersion via sonication with 5 mL of EtOH. After the removal of the EtOH supernatant via centrifugation at 10 000 rpm for 10 min, the microcrystals with a yield of 77% (3a) or 81% (3b) (based on Hpypa) were prepared.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 3's Microcrystals 3a and 3b 

A solution of Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (17.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) or polyethylene glycol (PEG) 20000 (50 mg) and H2O (4 mL) was mixed and sonicated for 30 min until the whole PVP or PEG 20000 dissolved. DMF (4 mL) and Hpypa (10.8 mg, 0.05 mmol) was added into the PVP (or PEG 20000)/H2O mixture and it was sonicated for the other 30 min. Therewith, the mixture solution was put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave under 100 °C for 3 days. After being cooled, microcrystals were obtained via centrifugation at 10000 rpm in 10 10 min. Then, the supernatant was removed, and the microcrystals were produced by redispersion via sonication with 5 mL of EtOH. After the removal of the EtOH supernatant via centrifugation at 10 000 rpm for 10 min, the microcrystals with a yield of 77% (3a) or 81% (3b) (based on Hpypa) were prepared.

elements.content: The single-crystal data for 1–4 were performed on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractometer (MoKα, λ = 0.71073 Å). The data corrections were executed by Lorentz and polarization effects. Absorption corrections were used with the CrystalClear (Rigaku/MSC Inc., 2006) program. A full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 with the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package was used to solve and refine the whole structures. H atoms were fixed at the calculated positions refined with isotropic displacement parameters using the riding atoms. Crystallographic parameters and structure data refinements of 1–4 are provided in . Selected bond lengths [Å] and bond angles [deg] of 1–4 are given in Table S2. Crystallographic data for 1–4 have been stored at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. CCDC reference numbers: 1470711–1470714.

Single Crystal Data Collection and Refinement

The single-crystal data for 1-4 were performed on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractometer (MoKα, λ = 0.71073 Å). The data corrections were executed by Lorentz and polarization effects. Absorption corrections were used with the CrystalClear (Rigaku/MSC Inc., 2006) program. A full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 with the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package was used to solve and refine the whole structures. H atoms were fixed at the calculated positions refined with isotropic displacement parameters using the riding atoms. Crystallographic parameters and structure data refinements of 1-4 are provided in . Selected bond lengths [Å] and bond angles [deg] of 1-4 are given in Table S2. Crystallographic data for 1-4 have been stored at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. CCDC reference numbers: 1470711-1470714.

Aryl halides (0.5 mmol, 1.0 equiv), (microscale) catalysts 1–4 (0.05 mmol, 0.1 equiv grounded on metal ions), and magnesium turnings (0.6 mmol, 1.2 equiv) were mixed together and refluxed in anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (2 mL) under dry air. After 6 h, the cool reacting solution was filtrated. The solution was then diluted with acetic ether, and the combined organic layers were extracted with water and then dried MgSO4, filtered, and evaporated in a vacuum. Purification of the raw product by column chromatography on silicagel with hexane provided the pure products (entry 9–24 with hexane–EtOAc = 4:1, entry 25–28 with hexane–AcOEt = 10:1). Column chromatography was implemented with 200–300 mesh silica gel. 1HNMR spectra were achieved by a 400 MHz instrument and 13C NMR spectra on a 100 MHz instrument (see Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
General Procedure of the Preparation of the Biaryl Compounds with 1-4 as Catalysts

Aryl halides (0.5 mmol, 1.0 equiv), (microscale) catalysts 1-4 (0.05 mmol, 0.1 equiv grounded on metal ions), and magnesium turnings (0.6 mmol, 1.2 equiv) were mixed together and refluxed in anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (2 mL) under dry air. After 6 h, the cool reacting solution was filtrated. The solution was then diluted with acetic ether, and the combined organic layers were extracted with water and then dried MgSO4, filtered, and evaporated in a vacuum. Purification of the raw product by column chromatography on silicagel with hexane provided the pure products (entry 9-24 with hexane-EtOAc = 4:1, entry 25-28 with hexane-AcOEt = 10:1). Column chromatography was implemented with 200-300 mesh silica gel. 1HNMR spectra were achieved by a 400 MHz instrument and 13C NMR spectra on a 100 MHz instrument (see Supporting Information).

elements.content: According to single-crystal X-ray measure analysis, 1–4 are isostructural with the monoclinic space group P21/c. They all exhibit an infinite two-dimensional framework. Herein, only the detailed description of structure of 3 is provided. As illustrated in a, there are one Ni2+, two pypa–, and two coordination H2O. The Ni2+ ion is six-coordinated and shows a slightly distorted octahedral coordination environment. The Ni2+ is surrounded with two carboxylate oxygen (O2A, O2B) of two pypa–, two coordinated H2O molecules (Ni–O2 = 2.054 Å, Ni–O3 = 2.082 Å), and two nitrogen of two pypa–. Two coordinated H2O molecules in axial positions are good leaving groups and can be good for the contact of substrates with the metal sites in the catalytic reaction process. One Ni2+ center is connected by two aqua ligands to form a {Ni­(H2O)2}2+ secondary building unit (SBU). As shown in b, the pypa– acts as bridges linking {Ni­(H2O)2}2+ SBU to give rise to a two-dimensional layer structure. The two-dimensional structures of 3 further interact with each other to produce a supramolecular three-dimensional framework via O–H···O interactions between coordination water molecules (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

According to single-crystal X-ray measure analysis, 1-4 are isostructural with the monoclinic space group P21/c. They all exhibit an infinite two-dimensional framework. Herein, only the detailed description of structure of 3 is provided. As illustrated in a, there are one Ni2+, two pypa-, and two coordination H2O. The Ni2+ ion is six-coordinated and shows a slightly distorted octahedral coordination environment. The Ni2+ is surrounded with two carboxylate oxygen (O2A, O2B) of two pypa-, two coordinated H2O molecules (Ni-O2 = 2.054 Å, Ni-O3 = 2.082 Å), and two nitrogen of two pypa-. Two coordinated H2O molecules in axial positions are good leaving groups and can be good for the contact of substrates with the metal sites in the catalytic reaction process. One Ni2+ center is connected by two aqua ligands to form a {Ni(H2O)2}2+ secondary building unit (SBU). As shown in b, the pypa- acts as bridges linking {Ni(H2O)2}2+ SBU to give rise to a two-dimensional layer structure. The two-dimensional structures of 3 further interact with each other to produce a supramolecular three-dimensional framework via O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions between coordination water molecules (Figure S2).

X-ray Powder Diffraction Analyses and Thermogravimetric Analyses

PXRD patterns were obtained to verify the phase purity of 1-4. For 1-4, the synthesized PXRD patterns excellently match the simulated patterns based on the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data, indicative of pure compounds (Supporting Information Figure S3).

elements.content: Coordination polymers are latent function materials. The thermal stability is a significant index to confirm the application value. Therefore, TGA for 1–4 was carried out to examine their thermal stability. The TGA of 1 indicates a mass loss of 6.94% from 149 to 220 °C could be ascribed to the release of two coordination H2O molecules (calcd 6.93%). The framework starts to collapse from 288 °C. 2 demonstrates a totally decreased weight 6.95% at 161–236 °C, consistent with the expulsion of two associated H2O molecules (calcd 6.82%). Its further decline in mass marks the decomposition of the anhydrous complex. The TGA of 3 indicates the weight loss of 7.05% from 171 to 221 °C corresponds to the release of two coordinated H2O molecules (calcd 6.83%), and a second mass loss corresponds to the collapse of the whole framework. For 4, the first weight loss of 6.65% from 165 to 220 °C could be ascribed to the release of two coordinated H2O (calcd 6.76%). A second mass loss from 298 to 476 °C is associated with the collapse of the complex (Supporting Information Figure S4).

elements.content: The homocoupling reactions of aryl halides represent vigorous synthetic methods for symmetric biaryls and play an important role in good biochemical and medicinal industries. To date, using coordination polymers as heterogeneous catalysts has rarely been reported in the Ullmann reaction. Thus, we study the CPs-based catalysts for homocoupling of aryl halides in the use of metallic magnesium. Compared with the usual catalysts for this reaction, coordination polymers as catalysts have some advantages, such as the smaller amount of catalysts, mild reaction conditions, nonpoisonous, and environmental friendliness. Further, the isostructural 1–4 based on the same ligand and different metal ions will help to identify the relation between the central metals and catalytic performances. To research the catalytic activity of 1–4, we need to verify their stable existence in common solvents. Hence, the analyses of solvent resistance properties are first carried out. The solvent resistance property of 1–4 was researched by suspending these crystals in boiling tetrahydrofuran, N, N-dimethylformamide and toluene for 24 h because these solvents would be used as reaction solvents for the catalytic reactions. The result showed that 1–4 kept their original samples and skeleton structures. Then, a direct cross-coupling of iodobenzene catalyzed by 3 with different catalyst loading, different solvent in dry air at 0.5 mmol ratio under 70 °C was studied (). We chose 1.2 equiv magnesium for this reaction. As illustrated in , the reaction could be performed in tetrahydrofuran and ethyl ether which are common solvents for synthesizing Grignard reagents, and the best yields (65%) were obtained in tetrahydrofuran. Unfortunately, the catalytic reaction did not occur in the N,N-dimethylformamide and toluene due to the difficulty of Grignard reagent formation (entry 2 and 3). Thus, tetrahydrofuran was chosen for subsequent optimization of reaction solvents. Changing the catalyst loading, the result indicated that at least 10 mol % 3 was necessary to achieve the best yield because the small amount of catalysts could not catalyze the homocoupling reaction effectively (entry 5–7).
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Capacity of 1-4 

The homocoupling reactions of aryl halides represent vigorous synthetic methods for symmetric biaryls and play an important role in good biochemical and medicinal industries. To date, using coordination polymers as heterogeneous catalysts has rarely been reported in the Ullmann reaction. Thus, we study the CPs-based catalysts for homocoupling of aryl halides in the use of metallic magnesium. Compared with the usual catalysts for this reaction, coordination polymers as catalysts have some advantages, such as the smaller amount of catalysts, mild reaction conditions, nonpoisonous, and environmental friendliness. Further, the isostructural 1-4 based on the same ligand and different metal ions will help to identify the relation between the central metals and catalytic performances. To research the catalytic activity of 1-4, we need to verify their stable existence in common solvents. Hence, the analyses of solvent resistance properties are first carried out. The solvent resistance property of 1-4 was researched by suspending these crystals in boiling tetrahydrofuran, N, N-dimethylformamide and toluene for 24 h because these solvents would be used as reaction solvents for the catalytic reactions. The result showed that 1-4 kept their original samples and skeleton structures. Then, a direct cross-coupling of iodobenzene catalyzed by 3 with different catalyst loading, different solvent in dry air at 0.5 mmol ratio under 70 °C was studied (). We chose 1.2 equiv magnesium for this reaction. As illustrated in , the reaction could be performed in tetrahydrofuran and ethyl ether which are common solvents for synthesizing Grignard reagents, and the best yields (65%) were obtained in tetrahydrofuran. Unfortunately, the catalytic reaction did not occur in the N,N-dimethylformamide and toluene due to the difficulty of Grignard reagent formation (entry 2 and 3). Thus, tetrahydrofuran was chosen for subsequent optimization of reaction solvents. Changing the catalyst loading, the result indicated that at least 10 mol % 3 was necessary to achieve the best yield because the small amount of catalysts could not catalyze the homocoupling reaction effectively (entry 5-7).

Isolated yields after column chromatography.

Room temperature.

Because of these encouraging initial results with 3, a series of halide compounds for the homocoupling reaction were studied by using metallic magnesium and 10 mol % catalysts in tetrahydrofuran under 70 °C. As shown in , 3 and 4 can promote the catalytic homocoupling reaction of all tested aromatic halides, leading to the corresponding biaryls in good yields without byproducts. In 3 and 4, although the Ni­(II) and Cu­(II) ions are six-coordinated, the associated water molecules, which are a fine leaving group, are likely to depart during the catalytic process. As a result, the remaining unsaturated Ni and Cu sites (four-coordinated) are exposed to the reaction substrate, which will be beneficial to this reaction. Compared with 3 and 4, 2 only promoted closs-coupling of aryl iodide to the corresponding biaryls as the sole product. Unfortunately, 1 showed no catalytic activity for any of the tested aromatic halides. Because of the lower bond energy between C and I, iodobenzene exhibits a higher reaction activity than bromobenzene. So we conclude that the catalytic activity of 1–4 is 3 ≈ 4 > 2 > 1. A single-crystal structural study indicates that 1–4 are isostructural, and the most important factor exploiting the different catalytic activities of 1–4 is the center metal ions. Compared with the homogeneous catalysts, such as CoCl2, CuCl2, NiBr2, etc., the most common Lewis acid catalyst for homocoupling provided equal yields with 3 and 4 under the same reaction conditions. But as homogeneous catalysts, the compounds are almost impossible to reutilization. Furthermore, a hot filtration experiment was carried out. At the 15% transformation of 6a in the presence of 3 or 4 in 1 h, the catalysts were removed from the reaction mixture by passing through a sand core funnel, and the supernatant continued to react for 11 h. During the course, the transformation of the supernatant remained nearly unchanged.

It is well-known that heterogeneous catalysts usually show size-dependent physical and catalytic properties, since the catalytic performance relies on the surface area of solid catalysts and the dimension of substrates. Microscale coordination polymers exhibit large specific surface areas and show great promise for high density of catalytically active centers. To further improve the catalytic performance, microscale 3a and 3b were obtained with the addition of polyvinylpyrrolidone and polyethylene glycol 20000 as surfactants. As shown in a,b, 3a shows the particles with an approximately size of 3.0 × 2.0 μm, and 3b shows the particles with an approximately size of 4.0 × 2.0 μm. The cause of different morphologies and particle sizes of 3a and 3b could be ascribed to the nature of surface-active agents. Polyvinylpyrrolidone and polyethylene glycol 20000 act as capping agents to prohibit the growth of crystal nucleus, and the growth process of crystal nucleus can be quenched in the early days. The PXRD patterns of microscale crystals 3a and 3b compare well with the corresponding simulated patterns from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of 3, which indicate the microscale crystals 3a and 3b are crystalline and have the same crystal structure as 3 (e,f). Then, the homocoupling reactions of a variety of halide compounds with 3a and 3b as catalysts were investigated. As shown in , 3a and 3b exhibit better catalytic activities than 3 on the homocoupling of aryl iodide in 4 h.

The recyclability of 3 for the catalytic reaction with iodobenzene as the substrate was also examined. In the recycled and reused experiments, 3 was readily regained from the catalytic reaction by filtration, and the yield decreases about 7% in five cycles (a). Moreover, the PXRD pattern of 3 after the fifth catalytic reactions (more) closely matches that of single crystals 3 and shows the same as the skeleton structure, which shows that the structure remains intact after at least five runs (b).

elements.content: As shown in , we proposed a feasible mechanism for the catalytic reaction. First, the Grignard reagent is produced by aryl halides and magnesium. And the Grignard reagent is activated by the catalysts to form monosubstituted intermediate I. Then, I reacts with the Grignard reagent to give the diaryl-substituted intermediate II. Reductive elimination of II produces the homocoupling products and revives the catalytically active species.

Reductive elimination of II produces the homocoupling products and revives the catalytically active species.

elements.content: It has been observed that the catalytic performance of CPs-based heterogeneous catalysts is strongly dependent on the metal entities. The catalytic performance of the metals was largely governed by its Lewis acidity. The stronger the Lewis acidity, the larger the influence of the metals on the catalytic activation. To investigate the relation between metals and the catalytic performances, density functional theory was performed for the balanced geometry structures, the net charges of atom, and the energy of frontier molecule orbit via Gaussian 09 package. The unrestricted hybrid density functional UB3LYP was used to perform geometric structural optimization and charge analysis. The mixed basis set including LANL2DZ for Mn, Co, Ni, Cu, and 6-31G­(d, p) for C, H, and N was used in the calculations. The calculated bond lengths for 1–4 are in fine agreement with the experimental X-ray crystal structure, indicating that our calculated results are reasonable (Table S3).
elements.clean_text:
Influence of Metal Ions on Catalytic Activity

It has been observed that the catalytic performance of CPs-based heterogeneous catalysts is strongly dependent on the metal entities. The catalytic performance of the metals was largely governed by its Lewis acidity. The stronger the Lewis acidity, the larger the influence of the metals on the catalytic activation. To investigate the relation between metals and the catalytic performances, density functional theory was performed for the balanced geometry structures, the net charges of atom, and the energy of frontier molecule orbit via Gaussian 09 package. The unrestricted hybrid density functional UB3LYP was used to perform geometric structural optimization and charge analysis. The mixed basis set including LANL2DZ for Mn, Co, Ni, Cu, and 6-31G(d, p) for C, H, and N was used in the calculations. The calculated bond lengths for 1-4 are in fine agreement with the experimental X-ray crystal structure, indicating that our calculated results are reasonable (Table S3).

elements.content: According to frontier orbital theory, the frontier orbitals have the most important influence on the catalytic performance. The highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) is primarily to provide electrons, and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) is the electron acceptor. The smaller the LUMO energy, the more drop in energy after accepting electrons leading to a more stable system. In the homocoupling of aryl halides catalyzed by coordination polymers, Lewis acid catalysts act as electrophiles, and the lower energy of LUMO of coordination polymers is beneficial to promote the reaction. As shown in , the energy of LUMO of 1–4 is negative, and 4 < 3 < 2 < 1. It is accordance with the order of catalytic activity: 3 ≈ 4 > 2 > 1. A comparison of ΔE (ΔE = E LUMO – E HOMO) of 1–4 shows that 1 > 2 > 3 > 4. The larger ΔE is, the harder the intramolecular electron excitation is, the more stable and less active.

In the homocoupling of aryl halides catalyzed by coordination polymers, Lewis acid catalysts act as electrophiles, and the lower energy of LUMO of coordination polymers is beneficial to promote the reaction. As shown in , the energy of LUMO of 1-4 is negative, and 4 < 3 < 2 < 1. It is accordance with the order of catalytic activity: 3 ~ 4 > 2 > 1. A comparison of ΔE (ΔE = E LUMO - E HOMO) of 1-4 shows that 1 > 2 > 3 > 4. The larger ΔE is, the harder the intramolecular electron excitation is, the more stable and less active.

The net charge of the central metals in 1–4 is given in . These charges are positive and indicate that the central metals of the coordination polymers can still accept the electron of halogeno benzene to activate the halogeno benzene. The larger the net charge of the central metals is, the stronger is the ability to accept the electron. The order of the net charge is 3 > 4 > 2 > 1, conformity to the order of catalytic performances for 1–4.

elements.content: The difference of catalytic performance of 1–4 is attributed to three causes: (i) the higher net charge of the central metals shows a stronger ability to accept electrons; (ii) the coordination polymers with lower energy of lowest unoccupied molecular orbital more easily accept electrons; (iii) intramolecular electron excitation of the coordination polymers with smaller ΔE is easier and leads to better catalytic activity.

elements.content: We have prepared and characterized a series of isostructural two-dimensional coordination polymers [Mn­(pypa)2­(H2O)2] n (1), [Co­(pypa)2­(H2O)2] n (2), [Ni­(pypa)2­(H2O)2] n (3), and [Cu­(pypa)2­(H2O)2] n (4). The catalytic properties of the homocoupling of aromatic halides have been examined. 3 and 4 exhibit good catalytic activity on the homocoupling of aryl bromide or aryl iodide, while 2 only promotes the homocoupling of aryl iodide to the corresponding biaryls as the sole product. 1 shows no catalytic activity for all tested aromatic halides. The effect of the central metals on the catalytic property is explained via density functional theory. And 3’s microscale 3a and 3b exhibit better catalytic activity than 3.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have prepared and characterized a series of isostructural two-dimensional coordination polymers [Mn(pypa)2(H2O)2] n  (1), [Co(pypa)2(H2O)2] n  (2), [Ni(pypa)2(H2O)2] n  (3), and [Cu(pypa)2(H2O)2] n  (4). The catalytic properties of the homocoupling of aromatic halides have been examined. 3 and 4 exhibit good catalytic activity on the homocoupling of aryl bromide or aryl iodide, while 2 only promotes the homocoupling of aryl iodide to the corresponding biaryls as the sole product. 1 shows no catalytic activity for all tested aromatic halides. The effect of the central metals on the catalytic property is explained via density functional theory. And 3's microscale 3a and 3b exhibit better catalytic activity than 3.

Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O (29.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), Hpypa (10.8 mg, 0.05 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (4 mL) and H2O (4 mL) was added into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The container was then sealed and heated at 100 °C for 3 days. Then, the mixture was cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h; green crystals of 3 were obtained with a yield of 85% (based on Hpypa). Anal. Calcd for C22H24N6NiO6: C, 50.12; H, 4.59; N, 15.94. Found: C, 49.95; H, 4.59; N, 15.49. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3432(s), 3129(s), 3103(s), 2167­(m), 1619(s), 1565(s), 1495­(m), 1418(s), 1402(s), 1325(s), 1210­(m), 1108­(m), 1026­(w), 850­(m).

Synthesis of [Cu­(pypa)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

CuCl2·2H2O (17.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), Hpypa (10.8 mg, 0.05 mmol), acetonitrile (4 mL), and H2O (4 mL) was added into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The container was then sealed and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. Then, the mixture was cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h; blue green crystals of 4 were obtained with a yield of 83% (based on Hpypa). Anal. Calcd for C22H24N6CuO6: C, 49.67; H, 4.55; N, 15.80. Found: C, 49.80; H, 4.62; N, 15.63%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3435(s), 3120(s), 3093(s), 2237­(m), 1609(s), 1565(s), 1498­(m), 1428(s), 1402(s), 1345(s), 1201­(m), 1103­(m), 1016­(w), 847­(m).

Synthesis of 3’s Microcrystals <bold>3a</bold> and <bold>3b</bold>

A solution of Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O (17.4 mg, 0.1 mmol), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) or polyethylene glycol (PEG) 20000 (50 mg) and H2O (4 mL) was mixed and sonicated for 30 min until the whole PVP or PEG 20000 dissolved. DMF (4 mL) and Hpypa (10.8 mg, 0.05 mmol) was added into the PVP (or PEG 20000)/H2O mixture and it was sonicated for the other 30 min. Therewith, the mixture solution was put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave under 100 °C for 3 days. After being cooled, microcrystals were obtained via centrifugation at 10 000 rpm in 10 10 min. Then, the supernatant was removed, and the microcrystals were produced by redispersion via sonication with 5 mL of EtOH. After the removal of the EtOH supernatant via centrifugation at 10 000 rpm for 10 min, the microcrystals with a yield of 77% (3a) or 81% (3b) (based on Hpypa) were prepared.

cln_elements.content: Coordination polymers are latent function materials. The thermal stability is a significant index to confirm the application value. Therefore, TGA for 1–4 was carried out to examine their thermal stability. The TGA of 1 indicates a mass loss of 6.94% from 149 to 220 °C could be ascribed to the release of two coordination H2O molecules (calcd 6.93%). The framework starts to collapse from 288 °C. 2 demonstrates a totally decreased weight 6.95% at 161–236 °C, consistent with the expulsion of two associated H2O molecules (calcd 6.82%). Its further decline in mass marks the decomposition of the anhydrous complex. The TGA of 3 indicates the weight loss of 7.05% from 171 to 221 °C corresponds to the release of two coordinated H2O molecules (calcd 6.83%), and a second mass loss corresponds to the collapse of the whole framework. For 4, the first weight loss of 6.65% from 165 to 220 °C could be ascribed to the release of two coordinated H2O (calcd 6.76%). A second mass loss from 298 to 476 °C is associated with the collapse of the complex (Supporting Information Figure S4).
